meanings.definition: Hesitate or be unwilling to accept an idea or undertaking.
meanings.sent1: She would often balk at trying new foods.
meanings.sent2: He tends to balk when asked to speak in public.
meanings.sent3: The cat would balk at the idea of taking a bath.
meanings.sent4: His fear of failure made him balk at taking risks.
meanings.sent5: The child would always balk at bedtime, delaying sleep.

meanings.sent1: The fallen tree was a huge balk in the road.
meanings.sent2: The lack of funding proved to be a major balk in the project.
meanings.sent3: The rainy weather was a frustrating balk to their picnic plans.
meanings.sent4: The closed road was a significant balk to their travel route.
meanings.sent5: The technical issue was a sudden balk to their online meeting.

meanings.sent1: The carpenter carried a heavy balk across the construction site.
meanings.sent2: The old barn was supported by sturdy balks of wood.
meanings.sent3: The playful children used the balk as a makeshift balance beam.
meanings.sent4: The ancient castle featured balks of timber in its structure.
meanings.sent5: The farmer used the balk to reinforce the fence around the field.
